field_edited_text.value:
32

c. Merchants

The relatively low percentage of merchants who
own their properties makes it difficult to
encourage improvements that would enhance
the area and contribute to the concept of an
active and viable Town Center.

To the extent that the merchants are highly
dependent on the surrounding neighborhood
for their livelihood, they are committed to its
future. This commitment should be expanded
and deepened in the formulation of plans for
the creation of community centers by
encouraging the participation of merchants in
the decision-making process and providing
opportunities for them to improve their
premises.

d. Property Owners

Property owners fall into two

categories: Those who operate businesses in
the shopping centers and those who rent their
buildings to others. It is reasonable to presume
that those who conduct business in their own
premises have a higher degree of commitment
to the area than absentee landlords.

If the community center concept is to be
successfully implemented, property owners will
have to make'a heavier commitment to the
centers in which their properties are located.
This commitment can take the form of
participation in new investment programs
organized by groups of merchants and owners
banding together, and in other community
groups that recognize the community interest
and work on its behalf. The commitment will
also require improvements to property within
the framework of a general plan of
rehabilitation

3. Need for Cooperation

The program for the improvement of the
demonstration areas is designed, in part, to
establish new patterns of cooperation at the
city level among private enterprise, local
merchants, public agencies, and local residents.
Cooperative planning and program
implementation among these groups is
proposed to achieve the following major
objectives:

To provide the private retail and service
facilities that reflect the consumer needs of
local residents.



To promote maximum local community
identification with the use of the shopping
facilities.

To create a viable center of community interest
and activity as well as an economically
successful shopping center.

To create a functionally and physically
attractive asset in the overall neighborhood
rehabilitation program area.

To generate the maximum renewal of
productive investment and employrmient
opportunities for local residents.

To increase the assessable real estate tax base.

a. Citizens Advisory Council

Based on these objectives, it is essential that
communication with and participation of
neighborhood groups and individuals be
initiated early in the formulation of a
development program. Neighborhood
participation should perhaps be formalized into
a citizens advisory council with a clearly

delineated role in the formulation of policy and

program proposals.

Based on the findings, analyses and conclusions
of this study, a citizens advisory council can be
provided with an adequate basis for discussing
and contributing to major aspects of the
rehabilitation program. A program of
neighborhood participation would be an
excellent vehicle for identifying neighborhood
needs and attitudes that bear on
implementation of the rehabilitation program.
Moreover, this type of neighborhood
participation is likely to offer an effective
approach to dissemination of information to
neighborhood residents.

b. Small Business Commission

Within the existing framework of city
government, there is a need for an agency
directly concerned with the activities of small
businessmen within the community. A small
business commission with the necessary staff
could undertake certain important activities. It
could receive funds from the city government
for its operation, solicit funds from private
individuals or negotiate with other government
agencies at the federal or state level to carry out
programs.

By creating a Small Business Commission
(SBC), the city would be accepting the
responsibility for providing the needed
leadership. An SBC would:

Provide managerial training for small
businessmen

Become a clearinghouse for financial guidance
and assistance

Aid in loan application processing

Provide technical and other assistance in the
rehabilitation or construction of commercial
facilities and structures

Develop plans and programs for areas
containing primarily retailing and commercial
establishments

Coordinate its planning activities with those of
other city agencies

Coordinate development pfograms within
specified planning areas with other city agencies
providing supporting facilities and services

Provide fegal services to groups of merchants or
property owners banding together to form a
development corporation’ . A

Suggest to City Council legislation needed to
carry out its programs

In general, serve as liaison between the small
business community and city, state and federal
agencies

Every aspect of program initiation and
execution proposed in this study should be
carried out in close collaboration with
neighborhood groups.

4. Employment Opportunities

While it was outside the scope of the study to
discuss job opportunities for neighborhood
residents, it would be a severe oversight to
ignore this aspect of the potential program. The
success of the rehabilitation program would be
measurably improved by the creation of new
employment opportunities in the study areas.
Thus, there should be provision for generating
employment opportunities relating to existing
or proposed training programs.

a0
